paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.spark.streaming._
import org.apache.spark.streaming.twitter._
//import org.apache.bahir.spark.streaming.twitter._
import org.apache.spark.storage.StorageLevel
import scala.io.Source
import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
import java.io.File
import org.apache.log4j.Logger
import org.apache.log4j.Level
import sys.process.stringSeqToProcess
import twitter4j.HashtagEntity

val consumerKey = System.getenv("TWITTER_CONSUMER_KEY")
val consumerSecret = System.getenv("TWITTER_CONSUMER_SECRET")
val accessToken = System.getenv("TWITTER_ACCESS_TOKEN")
val accessTokenSecret = System.getenv("TWITTER_ACCESS_SECRET")

System.setProperty("twitter4j.oauth.consumerKey", consumerKey)
System.setProperty("twitter4j.oauth.consumerSecret", consumerSecret)
System.setProperty("twitter4j.oauth.accessToken", accessToken)
System.setProperty("twitter4j.oauth.accessTokenSecret", accessTokenSecret)

select from_unixtime(createdAt), count(1) from tweets group by createdAt order by createdAt

%sql

select  sentiment(text) as sentiment, text from tweets LIMIT 1

paragraphs.text:
%sql

--Ok, lets take a peek at sentiment with our function
--and make a plot

select  sentiment(text) as sentiment, count(1) from tweets group by sentiment(text)

%sql

--show most common words for negatives tweets

select word, sentiment, count(1) as cnt
from 
(
   select from_unixtime(createdAt) as created, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment,  text  from tweets
) sub1
lateral view explode(split(text, ' ')) t as word 
where sentiment = 'negative'
group by word, sentiment
having count(1) > 1
order by cnt desc

paragraphs.text:
%sql

--show most common words for positivie tweets

select word, sentiment, count(1) as cnt
from 
(
   select from_unixtime(createdAt) as created, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment,  text  from tweets
) sub1
lateral view explode(split(text, ' ')) t as word 
where sentiment = 'positivie'
group by word, sentiment
having count(1) > 1
order by cnt desc

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

#declaring a function in Python
#to count the number of words by splitting on white space

import re

def wordcount(a):
  return len(re.split("\W+",a))
  
sqlContext.registerFunction("wordcount", wordcount)

%sql
---maybe we want to know the word count associated with each

select  sentiment(text) as sentiment, wordcount(text) as wordcount, count(1) from tweets group by sentiment(text), wordcount(text)

paragraphs.text:
%sql
---maybe we want to know the raw counts by minute

select minute, sentiment, count(1) as cnt from
(
   select substr(from_unixtime(createdAt), 0, 16) as minute, screenName, sentiment(text) as sentiment, wordcount(text) as wordcount, text  from tweets
) sub1
group by minute, sentiment
order by minute
